qas.question: Zinc oxide is believed to be mentioned in what ancient text?
Active zinc mines in India date back to what period?
What process occurred around the 12th century?
When was the Rasaratna Samuccaya written?
What are the two uses of zinc ore mentioned in the Rasaratna Samuccaya?

answers.text: metal extraction and another used for medicinal purposes

qas.question: What ancient text forbids the use of Zinc oxide?
What period do active zinc mines in China date back to?
What process occurred around the 6th century?
When was the Rasaratna Samuccaya destroyed?
What is the only use of zinc ore mentioned in the Rasaratna Samuccaya?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>The Charaka Samhita<b5_0/><a0_0/>, thought to have been written between 300 and 500 AD, mentions a metal which, when oxidized, produces pushpanjan, thought to be zinc oxide. Zinc mines at Zawar, near Udaipur in India, have been active since the <a1_0><b6_0>Mauryan period<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The <a2_0><b7_0>smelting of metallic zinc<b7_0/><a2_0/> here, however, appears to have begun around the 12th century AD. One estimate is that this location produced an estimated million tonnes of metallic zinc and zinc oxide from the 12th to 16th centuries. Another estimate gives a total production of 60,000 tonnes of metallic zinc over this period. The Rasaratna Samuccaya, written in approximately the <a3_0><b8_0>13th century AD<b8_0/>,<a3_0/> mentions two types of zinc-containing ores: one used for <a4_0><b9_0>metal extraction<b9_0/> and another used for medicinal purposes<a4_0/>.
